problem_text:
We define the class of hierarchically decomposable groups in the following way. First, if X is any class of groups, then let H1X denote the class of groups which admit an admissible action on a finite-dimensional contractible complex in such a way that every cell stabilizer belongs to X. Then the “big” class HX is defined to be the smallest H1-closed class containing X.
∗a) Let F be the class of all finite groups. Find an example of an HF group which is not in H3F (= H1H1H1F).
b) Prove or disprove that there is an ordinal α such that HαF = HF, where Hα is the operator on classes of groups defined by transfinite induction in the obvious way starting from H1.
Editor’s comment: It is proved that such an ordinal cannot be countable (T. Januszkiewicz, P. H. Kropholler, I. J. Leary, Bull. London Math. Soc., 42, No. 5 (2010), 896–904).
P. Kropholler
answer: ∗a) Such an example is found; moreover, for any countable ordinal α there are groups in Hα+1F that are not in HαF (T. Januszkiewicz, P. H. Kropholler, I. J. Leary, Bull. London Math. Soc., 42, No. 5 (2010), 896–904). Furthermore, torsion-free examples with similar properies have been constructed (F. Fournier-Facio, B. Sun, Preprint, 2025, https://arxiv.org/abs/2503.01987v3).
